Title: The development of a social exclusion Agenda in French cultural policy
Affiliations: Department of French, University of Leeds, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Looseley, D., Department of French, University of Leeds, United Kingdom
Abstract: The article argues that developing a social exclusion agenda has, in various guises and terminologies (‘democratization’, ‘cultural democracy’, ‘cultural development’), been the driver of French cultural policy thinking and debate since the creation of a Ministry of Culture in 1959. Addressing exclusion has in fact been a perennial problem for the French ministry, because of a founding and apparently irrepressible conviction, from Malraux in the 1960s to Lang in the 1980s and 1990s, that art speaks for itself without mediation; and because of the consequent structural separation of (to use the standard French terminology) the ‘cultural’ from the ‘social’. This conviction was contested in the late 1960s—partly with the help of Bourdieu's notion of cultural capital, although since then policy agents have mostly attempted to move on from Malraux's position by taking up positions against Bourdieu. The article traces the history of these attempts, then examines in more detail the principles, problems and paradoxes of the exclusion agenda in French cultural policy today. © 2004, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Capitals, ethnic identity and educational qualifications
Affiliations: Centre of the Study of Ethnicity and Citizenship, University of Bristol, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Modood, T., Centre of the Study of Ethnicity and Citizenship, University of Bristol, United Kingdom
Abstract: Cultural capital analysis, or class analysis more generally, exacerbates rather than resolves the anomaly of why non-white ethnic minorities in Britain are over-represented in higher education. Some of these groups have a disproportionate lower, socio-economic profile and yet at least some of these groups are more likely to pursue and achieve entry into higher education than whites, especially, their white working-class peers. They also suffer additional disadvantages such as racism and cultural marginality. Bourdieu's concept of cultural capital is designed to explain why members of a disadvantaged class achieve less educational success than an advantaged class. It is not helpful in explaining why some disadvantaged groups do better than one would have predicted on the basis of a class (and/or racism) analysis. On the other hand, US sociological studies which deploy the concept of social capital in combination with ethnicity to explain the trajectories of ‘second generation’ migrants seem promising. This conclusion is offered on the basis of a brief literature review and a suggestion that the ‘motor’ of the British South Asian and Chinese overcoming of disadvantage lies in migrant parents getting their children to internalize high educational ambitions and to enforce appropriate behaviour. © 2004, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Developing the evidence base for UK film strategy: The research process at the UK Film Council
Affiliations: UK Film Council, 10 Little Portland St, London, W1W 7JG, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Steele, D., UK Film Council, 10 Little Portland St, London, W1W 7JG, United Kingdom
Abstract: The UK Film Council established a Research and Statistics Unit in order to gather data relating to film to inform the development of UK Film Council strategy and to provide an information service to the industry, government, the arts and cultural sector and the wider research community. The Research and Statistics Unit draws data from both official and unofficial sources and commissions its own special-purpose studies to gather information relevant to the strategic objectives of the Council. Key tasks are the measurement of the size of the market for film and the various elements of the film value chain, the performance of films supported by the UK Film Council and the performance of UK films in general. Special-purpose research projects currently include a detailed survey of the film production workforce, a study of the economic impact of the UK screen industries and studies of the social impact of local cinemas and the experience of Black- and Minority-led film production companies. A range of industry and official partners are collaborating in these studies. The Research and Statistics Unit also provides statistical and policy analysis relating to the wider policy environment of UK film, including issues such as the future of film tax incentives. This analysis has been developed within the HM Treasury ‘Green Book’ framework with particular reference to understanding market failure in relation to film. Central to the market failure argument is the cultural value of film in both its qualitative and its quantitative aspects. UK Film Council research is placed in the context of the literature on hedonic pricing and contingent valuation. The industrial challenges of increasing cultural value are discussed. Finally, consideration is given to the potential of film to contribute directly to ‘public value’. © 2004, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Author Keywords: Contingent Valuation; Cultural Policy; Cultural Value; Market Failure; Public Value; UK Film

Title: Why heritage counts: Researching the historic environment
Affiliations: English Heritage, 23 Savile Row, London, W1S 2ET, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Cowell, B., English Heritage, 23 Savile Row, London, W1S 2ET, United Kingdom
Abstract: The role of English Heritage in commissioning new research into the historic environment is considered. The place of research within the organization and the priorities for research as highlighted in the proposed English Heritage Research Strategy are set out. Research commissioned or carried out by English Heritage covers a wide range of areas, from archaeology and buildings history to applied conservation research. However, the focus of the article is on research that addresses social, economic and policy issues. Work that has been carried out by English Heritage in three areas is explored: the economic value of heritage investment; issues of social inclusion and access to heritage; and analysis of the threats faced by the historic environment and the resources available to address these threats. A key driver for this research activity is the annual Heritage Counts report produced by English Heritage on behalf of the wider heritage sector. © 2004, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: Local cultural strategies: A strategic review
Affiliations: Arts Council England, North West Manchester House, 22 Bridge Street, Manchester, M3 3AB, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Gilmore, A., Arts Council England, North West Manchester House, 22 Bridge Street, Manchester, M3 3AB, United Kingdom
Abstract: The development of Local Cultural Strategies was recommended to all local authorities in England through the publication of a guidance document, Creating Opportunities, by the Department of Culture Media and Sport (DCMS, 2000). Although not a statutory duty, by the end of 2002 Local Cultural Strategy development was strongly encouraged by the government, and the adoption of a strategy became part of performance review for local authorities under Best Value Performance Indicator BVPI 114. This recommendation encouraged local authorities to formalize and publish plans for the strategic development of their cultural and culture-related services. These used a broad definition of culture and recognized of the value of partnership working within localities, regions and sub-regions in which local authorities were taking the ‘lead’. It also reflected the advocacy of a cultural planning approach by central government for local government. Cultural planning encourages a culturally sensitive approach to local cultural development, focusing on a diverse range of ‘cultural resources’, including leisure and sports facilities, qualities of natural and built environment, youth and ethnic communities and communities of interest, as well as the need for different local authority service departments and private, voluntary and other public sector partners to be involved early on in strategic development. According to this approach, culture is broadly defined as a ‘way of life’, and DCMS's guidance states that Local Cultural Strategies should promote cultural well-being and the quality of life in their designated areas. As a result, Local Cultural Strategies have been developed at all tiers of English local authorities, including district and borough, metropolitan and unitary authority, county and regional levels. This article discusses the development of Local Cultural Strategies in England and reviews information on those strategies that have been developed. It examines the different approaches local authorities have taken towards this task, the methodologies for consultation employed, the frameworks for monitoring and the evaluation of cultural provision they offer. It considers the benefits and problems associated with the production of Local Cultural Strategies as strategic development frameworks for local culture, and questions the future of this process following their ‘subsumption’ into Community Strategies as part of a broader package of reforms for local government. In doing so, it examines how these documents offer an opportunity to examine local approaches to cultural planning. © 2004, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: English cultural services: Government policy and local strategies
Affiliations: Heritage Lottery Fund, University of Leeds, United Kingdom; Department of Communication, Design and Media, University of Westminster, United Kingdom

Funding Text 1: There consequently seems to be a measure of optimism for the developments in Sheffield. From the mid-1980s Sheffield's museums suffered regular annual cuts, a reflection of the City Council's general financial problems. In 1994 the Museums Department and the Arts Department were integrated under a Leisure Directorate, and Kelham Island Industrial Museum was transferred to an independent charitable trust with grant aid from the City Council, in partnership with Sheffield Hallam University and the Company of Cutlers in Hallamshire. In April 1998 the City Council created the Sheffield Galleries and Museums Trust to manage four existing museums and art galleries and the new Millennium Gallery (opening 2000). The latter was part of a £20 million 'Heart of the City' project and the new Trust was also supported by an Arts Council of England Stabilisation Award of £1.15 million. Revenue funding has been secured for six years with a legal agreement that binds the City to provide an annual grant based on 1997/98 core budget, with a review in the third year to respond to inflation.The City is obliged to provide 'reasonable' funding to sustain the new organisation for a further four years (Middleton, 1998: 24-5).

Funding Text 1: Since 1992/93, the government department with most responsibility for the UK film industry has been the Department of National Heritage (DNH). Prior to this the industry received financial support from the Office of Arts and Libraries (OAL). The 1995 annual report of the DNH outlines the department's medium-term objectives in relation to film, which are to: (a) establish a framework that will allow the industry to thrive; (b) promote the UK as a location for the filming of feature films, television programmes and commercials; (c) expand opportunities for access to high- quality films from Britain and elsewhere; and (d) foster international cooperation in the production, distribution and exhibition of films.

The SFC, which has the remit to promote all aspects of the moving image in Scotland, received £1.019 million from the Scottish Office in 1994/95. In April 1996, following the publication of a report, Scotland on Screen, commissioned from Hydra Associates, the Secretary of State for Scodand announced a package of measures to strengthen the government's support for the film and television industry in Scotland. These measures include the formation of a new body, the Scottish Screen Agency, which will absorb the functions of the SFC, the SFPF and two other film agencies. The new body will operate from 1997.
Funding Text 4: There is no direct government support for the film industry in Wales. The Northern Ireland Film Council (NIFC) receives public funding from the Arts Council of Northern Ireland (ACNI) in the form of a revenue grant (£100,000 in 1994/95). It is anticipated that in 1997 the ACNI will devolve responsibility for the development of cultural film activity in Northern Ireland to the NIFC (which will then be directly funded by the Northern Ireland Office of Education).

Funding Text 1: Chapter 5 examines employment in the cultural sector. In recent years, the cultural sector has been promoted not only for its intrinsic contribution to national life but also for its extrinsic contribution as a source of economic regeneration and as a creator of jobs. This chapter makes clear that the sector is an important source of jobs in the economy. It shows that the jobs in question are very heterogeneous, that some are highly paid and some lowly paid, that some are rather precarious and unemployment is not infrequent, even if there are also many people who have worked for a single organisation for a long time. Many people in the sector work for themselves or are self-employed and in certain sub-sectors, volunteers are important providers of labour. Cultural Trends is completely independent: it offers a compilation and unbiased assessment of material from both published and unpublished sources. It relies on the goodwill and cooperation of many organisations and individuals in the sectors concerned. They provide many of the figures, offer information and advice - but the conclusions are, unless otherwise stated, the authors' own. We would like to thank Andy Feist, Arts Council of England; Michael Trickey, Arts Council of Wales; Margaret Prythergch, Michael Seeney, Sian Morgan and Lynn Gates, Department of National Heritage; Jeremy Warren and Alex Hurley, Museums & Galleries Commission; L M Mawhinney, Department of Education Northern Ireland; Christine Hamilton, Scottish Arts Council; Peter Donachie, Scottish Office; Julia Amour, Scottish Higher Education Funding Council; and Ian Miller and Gwilym Evans, Welsh Office. Funding Text 3: On the other hand, the Museums & Galleries Commission distributes financial support in the form of project grants to museums and associated organisations throughout the UK. It also provides grants to the seven English area museum councils, which in turn offer limited grant assistance, advice and advocacy to the museums within their regions.9The area museum councils are membership organisations, generating further income from museums, local authorities, universities and other institutions in their areas. They perform an important strategic role within their respective regions, contributing to policy formation at national level and advising the Museums & Galleries Commission on regional issues. However, the funds they distribute are relatively small (most funding being distributed by the Museums & Galleries Commission itself) and for this reason they are not analysed separately within this section.
Funding Text 4: Museums & Galleries Commission's regional funding is its grants to the area museum councils. In 1995/96, these accounted for £4.1 million, approximately 70 per cent of the Museums & Galleries Commission's regionally divisible expenditure. The Museums & Galleries Commission also operates a number of grant schemes through which financial assistance is channelled directly to museums and galleries. These schemes include purchase grants and capital grants. The Museums & Galleries Commission does not, as a rule, distribute revenue funding. However, it provides a grant of approximately £1 million to the Tyne & Wear Museums Service, which has 15 museums and galleries. The subsidy has been provided since the abolition of the metropolitan county council in 1986 to help the Tyne & Wear districts provide a county-wide museums service. The subsidy, which has now run for ten years, is currently under review. Purchase grants are awarded to museums wishing to add to their collections. There are two types of purchase grant, both administered on behalf of the Museums & Galleries Commission by national museums. The Museums & Galleries Commission/V&A Purchase Grant Fund, as its title suggests, is administered by the Victoria & Albert Museum. It is intended to assist museums and galleries acquire objects relating to the fine arts, history and literature. The Fund for the Preservation of Industrial and Scientific Material is administered by the Science Museum and is used to help museums acquire and conserve items relating to science and technology. A total of £1.3 million was awarded through the purchase grant schemes in 1995/96, approximately 20 per cent of the total grant expenditure analysed in this section.
Funding Text 5: In the financial year 1995/96the Heritage Lottery Fund made 302 grant awards, of which 60 were awarded to museums and galleries in England. These represented a total allocation of £113 million, and were for a range of activities which included acquisitions, refurbishment and construction work. Table 1.13 provides a breakdown of these grants by area museum council region. Funding Text 1: Funding for the built heritage from the European Commission (EC) is channelled in two ways: both through DGX, the Directorate-General responsible for Information, Communication, Culture and Audiovisual Policy, and through the structural funds. It is, of course, possible for heritage projects to obtain funding from a wider range of European Union programmes than this (for example, research and development) if they fulfil the programme criteria.
Funding Text 2: The SPAB was founded in 1887. It is the oldest of the National Amenity Societies, predating even the National Trust. At 31 December 1994, the SPAB had 6,377 members. At the time of writing, accounts for the financial year were not available, so the figures given here refer to 1993/94. The total income of the SPAB that year was £313,596. Thirty-five per cent of its total income (£109,873) came from courses and events, rental income and other sources such as bank interest. Contributions, donations and subscriptions amounted to 28 per cent (£86,573). Grants from the DOE, the Welsh Office and the J Mason Trust accounted for 17 per cent of its income. Life memberships provided less than 5 per cent. The SPAB's expenditure was £339,467. Its operational deficit of £25,871 was covered by the society's accumulated fund.
Funding Text 3: The CBA was founded in 1943 in response to devastation caused by war. The CBA is concerned with archaeological sites, and its key activities comprise research, conservation, education, information and publication. The total income of the CBA in 1994/95 was £474,485. Core funding for the CBA comes from the British Academy. In addition to the DNH grant, the CBA also received funds from Cadw for casework, and from EH towards the production of archaeological publications and the Young Archaeologists Club. These and other, smaller grants made accounted for over 70 per cent of its income. Subscriptions from the Council's 410 member societies and organisations generated about 10 per cent of its income, and affiliation fees less than 5 per cent. The Council earned £79,356 - 17 per cent of income - from sales of and subscriptions to publications, insurance commission, advertising revenue, and agency work. Investments rendered up less than 1 per cent. The CBA's expenditure was £473,567.
Funding Text 4: The DOE(NI)'s grants for the conservation of the built heritage in 1994/95 are given in Table 2.9. The amount distributed represents about 5 per cent of EH's giving. It made grants under five headings: to the National Trust; matching funding for the European Commission's Tourism Sub-Programme; churches; district councils; and to private individuals for their properties. Over half its grant funding went to properties in private hands. By comparison, district councils received about 6 per cent, and churches less.
Funding Text 5: As part of its support for the urban programme, the DOE sponsors English Partnerships, the urban regeneration agency, which promotes job creation, inward investment and environmental improvement, through the reclamation and development of vacant, derelict or contaminated land. English Partnerships became operational in April 1994, when it assumed responsibility for the former Derelict Land Grant and City Grant programmes, and the Direct Development programmes. The latter had been the responsibility of English Estates and were funded by the Department of Trade and Industry. The Derelict Land Grant encouraged local authorities, the private sector and voluntary bodies to carry out environmental improvement projects, while the City Grant encouraged private sector investment in projects to improve run-down urban areas.
Funding Text 6: (e) Sum sreceivedfromotheragencies.Th9seotheragenciesincludeEnglishHeritage, Department oftheEnvironment, European Regional Development Funds, the Rural Development Commission, Housing Corporation, etc.
Funding Text 7: Grants are a major source of income for the NTS. In 1994/95, these represented over 38 per cent of its income. These came from the European Regional Development Fund; Forestry Commission; HS; local authorities and Local Enterprise Companies; NHMF and HL; Scottish Homes; Scottish National Heritage; the Scottish Tourist Board; and the Scottish Office Agriculture and Fisheries Department. Endowment grants were worth just over £8 million, while grants for capital projects accounted for just over £3 million and revenue grants £0.3 million.
Funding Text 8: AHF's feasibility grants programme is funded through the Heritage Grants Fund. By the end of 1994/95, the AHF had disbursed £146,368 in grants for 70 studies.
References: The difficulties of defining ‘the built heritage’ can be illustrated by considering the interests of different bodies which support the sector The National Heritage Memorial Fund, one of the major funding bodies for heritage in the UK, for example, allocates grants according to five categories of heritage: ancient monuments, , historic buildings and sites; land of scenic, scientific or historic importance; printed books, manuscripts, archives and other records; museum and gallery collections; and industrial and maritime heritage. Its first category largely corresponds with the Department of National Heritage’s (DNH’s) working definition of the built heritage. However, the DNH embraces elements of the environment that have legal protection, and includes registered gardens and conservation areas. It also supports Royal Parks and historic wrecks; English Heritage (EH) is primarily concerned with the conservation of the ‘historic environment’ including the provision of advice to the DNH on the listing of buildings, scheduling of ancient monuments, and registration of conservation areas, , EH also keeps non-statutory registers of historic parks, gardens and battlegrounds. Historic Scotland (HS), an executive agency of the Scottish Office charged with the protection, conservation and presentation of Scotland’s built heritage, describes the built heritage as including ‘ancient monuments and archaeological sites; historic, buildings; parks and gardens, and designed landscapes’. Cadw, the executive agency of the Welsh Office responsible for preservation and conservation of the built heritage in Wales, is concerned with historic buildings and ancient monuments and is currently producing a register of parks and gardens; (1996) Department of National Heritage press release, DNH 145/96, , 15 May; Unfortunately, at the time of writing, the other National Amenity Societies were unable or unwilling to give details of their accounts for the time period covered here, or for the previous financial year, , Therefore it is not possible to include details of their income and expenditure here; (1994) Of the 57 trusts which provided usable information, 11 could only give figures for the financial year 1994/95 or the calendar year, , Many of the trusts which provided figures for the financial year 1994/95 had different year-ends. Despite these caveats, all 57 replies have been used in the calculation of charitable expenditure on the built heritage. Only one trust failed to provide a breakdown of its charitable giving. Consequently its contribution to the built heritage could not be disaggregated from its contribution to the ‘environment’. Not all schedules of donations were complete: one trust, for example, only included details of major grants. In four cases it was unclear whether the donations listed were paid in the period, or merely approved. In three cases, trusts which themselves made grants were in receipt of charitable donations from other trusts. In order to avoid double counting, the latter were deducted. Given these difficulties, it must be emphasised that figures being discussed here are not an accurate estimation of the input of charitable trusts into the built heritage sector, but should be viewed more as a minimum level of such input; Unfortunately, three trusts supplied details of their spending on the built heritage sector, but did not include their total charitable giving, , Of this figure, £7.6 million appears to have gone to the built heritage. The reason the word ‘appears’ is used is because the purpose of the grant was not always given, so it was not always clear exactly what the money was to be used for. For example, money going to individual churches may not always have been used for repairing the fabric of the buildings, but for furnishings. Several donations identified were to the National Trust and the National Trust for Scotland, but some were general donations and may have been used for interiors of properties or for properties with no built element

Title: Cinema, Film and Home Video
Funding Details: Department of Trade and Industry, DTI
Funding Text 1: The pattern of public funding for film in the UK has been going through a period of minor change over the last twelve months. British Screen Finance Ltd continues to receive funding to support production. A contract for a continued grant from the DTI was agreed in late 1991 lasting until 1993. This was at the current level of assistance (£2 million per annum). The Department of Trade and Industry is also contributing an additional £5 million over the next three years to the European Co-Production Fund, administered by British Screea The 1992 Budget saw a mild improvement in the tax regime for film production, with relief for pre-production expenditure to be available as it is incurred and production expenditure available for write off at a fixed rate of one third each year.
Funding Text 2: 1992 also saw the establishment of the British Film Commission (BFQ. The BFC is a Department of Trade and Industry-funded body which is intended to act as a focus for marketing the UK as a base for productions by foreign-based companies (mainly North American-based companies but with a keen eye on European opportunities). The skills of the UK's human resources, studios and settings are highlighted by the promotional activities of the Commission, which is being funded by a £3.5 million grant over four years from the DTI.

Title: 1 Arts festivals
Funding Text 1: Forty-five per cent of festivals received income from their regional arts board for their most recent festival, with the amount of support ranging from £ 100 to £58,500. The festivals receiving the highest funding from this source, at over £30,000, were the Huddersfield Contemporary Music Festival (£31,000), the Bristol Proms Festival (£55,000) and the London International Festival of Theatre (£58,500). Twenty per cent received funding from National Arts Council for their most recent festival, with the amount of financial support ranging from £33 to £590,000. Three festivals received over £200,000: the Belfast Festival at Queen's University (£222,000), the London International Festival of Theatre (£255,000) and the Edinburgh International Festival (£590,000).
Funding Text 2: In some cases festivals have made successful applications for funding from charitable trusts or received funding from tourist boards or development boards. Another area of revenue generation is sales of goods, including programmes, books, T-shirts and posters. Following advice from a consultant the B ath Festival quadrupled its income from this source according to The Economist, 5 August 1989. Other sources of funding include bank interest and income from advertising.

Funding Text 2: spending on the arts and museums over time, it is most sensible to use 1986/7 as the benchmark year. Direct comparisons between pre-and post-1986/7 spending levels in England are not at all easy to make. The consequences of abolition continue to influence the comparability of annual spending figures. The Geffrye and Homiman museums, funded by the GLC until 1986, were transferred to the Inner London Education Authority on abolition. When the ILEA was itself abolished in 1990, the Geffrye and Horniman museums became independent charitable trusts, funded by the Museums and Galleries Commission.

Total revenue expenditure on museums and the arts by the four main departments was £298 million. (The figure of £298 million excludes the Natural History Museum, which, as noted, ought to be excluded to allow a more realistic comparison with previous years. If OAL revenue expenditure on the Natural History Museum is added in museum expenditure becomes £134 million and total revenue expenditure on the arts and museums becomes £314 million, 1989/90). For the national museums funded by the OAL and the SOED, the capital element has been taken to include all expenditure on buildings and maintenance. The largest increase in revenue expenditure on arts support has been in Northern Ireland; Department of Education (NI) expenditure in this area - largely made up of the annual grant to the Arts Council Northern Ireland - increased by 21 per cent in real terms between 1986/7 and 1989/90.

Funding Text 5: Making effective comparisons between per capita expenditure levels in the four national arts councils is hindered by the fact that each has a slightly different set of responsibilities. The Welsh Arts Council is responsible for film and crafts activity and receives grants from the British Film Institute and Crafts Council for these purposes. The Scottish Arts Council makes small annual grants for film, but principal responsibility for film in Scotland rests with the Scottish Film Council. Funding for crafts in Scotland is shared between Scottish Enterprise and Highlands Enterprise (formerly the Scottish Development Agency and the Highlands and Islands Development Board). ACNI has no discrete budget for crafts, funding being mainly in the form of grants to crafts businesses through the Local Enterprise Development Unit.

Funding Text 1: Central funding for the performed arts has been a more recent phenomenon. Some subsidies were paid to film-makers from 1916 and the Royal Opera House Covent Garden received three payments in the 1930s. It was the second world war which provided the initial stimulus for support of the performed arts. The Council for the Encouragement of Music and the Arts (CEMA) had been formed in the early years of the war to bring music and theatre to war workers. Although originally funded by the Pilgrim Trust, four months after its creation it received matching funds from the Board of Education. Initial involvement included very considerable support for amateur organisations, but eventually support for the amateur was all but dropped. The success of CEMA in stimulating audiences allowed the Pilgrim Trust to withdraw its funding, leaving government as sole financer.
Funding Text 2: After the war, CEMA became the Arts Council of Great Britain. The Scottish and Welsh Arts Councils are technically committees of the Arts Council of Great Britain although they enjoy a high degree of autonomy. The Arts Council of Northern Ireland was conceived during the war as a Northern Ireland CEMA, although it was funded by the Northern Ireland Ministry of Education. It became the Arts Council of Northern Ireland in 1963.

Funding Text 4: At face value, there has been a substantial increase in the real value of central government expenditure on the arts and museums during the 1980s. As table 1.7 shows, expenditure on the arts and museums increased from £110.6 million to £361.7 million between 1978/9 and 1988/9. At constant prices (deflated by the GDP deflator), the growth in arts and museum revenue expenditure isimpressive, increasing by 48per cent overthe period. However, part of this increase up to 1987/8 does not represent an increased financial commitment to the arts and museums, but instead reflects changes in the structure of funding at central and local government levels. The removal of a tier of local government, with the abolition of the metropolitan counties and the Greater London Council (GLC), brought additional financial responsibilities on central government Much of the responsibility for arts and museums funding previously undertaken by the GLC and metropolitan counties was transferred either to the relevant centrally-funded agency (Arts Council, British Film Institute or Museums and Galleries Commission), centralgovernment direct (inthe caseof the 'newly created' nationalmuseums on Merseyside) or the remaining tier of local government in the metropolitan areas (the successor districts and boroughs). In 1988/9, responsibility for funding of the Natural History Museum was transferred from the Department of Education and Science to the OAL. This added £21.7 million to the budget of the OAL. Part of the increase in total expenditure by the OAL in 1988/9 was accounted for by higher levels of spending on the building and maintenance of the national museums.

Title: France
Funding Details: Masonic Cancer Center, University of Minnesota, MCC
Funding Text 1: The French state has a long history of involvement in the arts dating back to the ancien régime. The monarchy, especially under Louis XTV, had been great patrons of French cultural life. Many of the greatculturalinstitutionsinParisdatefrom theearly seventeenth and late eighteenth centuries. The Comedie Française, the Opéra Comique and the AcadémieRoyaldelaMusique (whichsubsequently became the Opéra), all relied on the financial support of the monarchy. When the monarchy was finallysweptawayin 1791,theRepublic,in effect, nationalised the country's existing cultural institutions; and the Louvre, intended as a museum of the republic, was established in 1793.
Funding Text 2: For literature and film the funding situation is complicated by key intermediary organisations funded only in part by the MCC. In 1975 the MCC set up a Department of Literature to bring together responsibilities previously held by three other ministries. Prior to this, in 1973, the Centre National des Lettres was formed with the aim of promoting creative writing and the publication, translation and dissemination of literary works. The Centre receives a part of its income (21 million francs) from the MCC and this represents around one third of the MCC's expenditure on literature outside of funding for the libraries (including the National Library) and public archives. The remainder of the Centre's income is derived from a 0.2 per cent tax on book sales and 3 per cent tax on copying equipment The latter raised around 16 million francs in 1986, out of a total budget of just under 100 million francs. Not all.of the Centre's expenditure is within the scope of this comparative study - just under three quarters goes to supporting publishers and dissemination via libraries.
